The company seems bound to fare only as well as their cyclical market. Compensation waxes and wanes accordingly. Negligible internal accountability. DRAM is essentially a commodity with Maxim one of 3 players. So if another company decides to increase production, all experience pricing pressure.
Advice to Management
Get more focused on meaningful compensation metrics. There's currently a somewhat idealistic executive focus on lofty corporate metrics rather than meaningful "in the trenches" feedback for individuals. Other than sheer professionalism (which varies) there's little individual accountability. I get the impression many of the mid level managers sort of phone it in & would get schooled if they were placed in even an average mixed signal house. I'm mostly talking design engineering, but especially the fabs. It's a VERY risk averse, almost timid environment. They will never kick Sung of Sam's posterior while trying to hang 40 switch options on mundane internal signals. There is a CYA design mentality that essentially turns potentially sleek chips into swiss army knifes.
Helpfu

review_title: Numerous opportunities for growth in responsibilities and compensation
pros: Great mobility and career growth, ample training and competitive compensation. Smaller, semi-independent division featured a family-like atmosphere where it was easy to get noticed and talent was rewarded.
cons:
At higher levels (corporate headquarters), things are more cutthroat, every one for him or herself. Commitments are sometimes made and broken without hesitation. 

Numerous opportunities for growth in responsibilities and compensation, until...changes in leadership resulted in a bait-and-switch substitution of a different job in place of the one that I was recruited aggressively into - different duties, different boss, completely different package. In short, a deal I would have rejected three months earlier when the original deal was offered. New boss saw himself as a cheerleader, but ability to inspire was absent.
Advice to Management
No company would allow a middle manager to dispose of a piece of valuable equipment without oversight. Long-time employees have real value that can be calculated in dollars. Before allowing a manager to get rid of someone for personal reasons, questions should be asked about how that employee got where they are -- years of demonstrated ability, talent and growth -- and why they are suddenly deemed useless and worthy of being tossed out. Curiosity of this type is missing here, replaced with blind support of managers, who sometimes make mistakes.

pros: Large amount of opportunity to advance, the turnover rate at the MTV (Micron Technology Virginia) site is high, if you have no life and want to work 60 hours a week for 40 hours’ worth of pay then MTV is the right place for you.
cons:
You will be doing the work that two or three people should be doing, the company keeps the labor force low to make budget. Living in a place where the cost of living is high does not help the company keep employees, there is a constant revolving door with employees. I do not blame the company for the situation we are in, having a manufacturing plant a few miles away from D.C. is not an obvious choice. If you are fresh out of college with an engineering degree MTV is a good place for you to gain experience, but once you have two kids and a mortgage you should start looking elsewhere.

pros: Boise is a terrific place to live and work and it is this safe small town feel that keeps many at Micron. The work is challenging and there is often room for creativity. As of late, greater hiring has been responsible for more upbeat fortunes (but the semiconductor memory industry fluctuates regularly).
cons:
Politicking and advancement through pedigree are part of the culture at Micron. Most experiences with management convince that they would have been much better off staying as independent contributors because they do not care for development or work/life balance. Poorly managed to the top with little hope of overtaking competition without significant changes.
Advice to Management
Focus more on the people that while the claim was always made are the most important, are not treated as such. Set promotion guidelines and stick to them. Investigate more than M&A for growth.
